channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Businesses Brace for Currency Chaos in Asia
item.description: A 1997 financial catastrophe casts a long shadow in countries that are seeing the value of their money plunge to record lows.
item.dc:creator: Daisuke Wakabayashi and Ben Dooley
item.media:credit: Lauren DeCicca for The New York Times
item.media:description: A vendor at a street market in Phuket, Thailand. Many businesses in Asia are being squeezed by the strength of the dollar, which has soared to record levels this year.

item.title: Britain’s Economic Experiment Stumbles at the Start
item.description: Prime Minister Liz Truss says a mix of tax cuts and deregulation is needed to jump-start Britain’s sluggish economy. Investors, economists and some in Truss’s own party disagree.
item.dc:creator: Eshe Nelson
item.media:credit: Alex Ingram for The New York Times
item.media:description: Many economists argue that, for Britain to turn around its low productivity and sluggish economy, the government will need to find ways to increase the supply of workers, among other improvements.

item.title: Scouting for Firewood, or for Russia? On the Front Line in Ukraine.
item.description: Outside the city of Lyman, Ukrainian troops ran across a 69-year-old Soviet veteran. He was placed in an improvised blindfold. All were enveloped in the fog of war.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Natalia Yermak and Nicole Tung
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers escorting a 69-year-old man named Aleksandr, whom they suspected of spying for the Russians, near the city of Lyman in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Russia’s Small Nuclear Arms Are a Risk For Putin and Ukraine
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia has 2,000 small nuclear weapons, but their utility on the battlefield may not be worth the longer-term costs.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger and William J. Broad
item.media:credit: Alexander Nemenov/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The atomic threats of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia may come as a shock to Americans who have barely thought about nuclear arms in recent decades.

item.title: Floridians Hit by a Hurricane and a Housing Crunch
item.description: Losses from the storm are just coming into focus. But what is clear is that recovery will be hardest on people already struggling to make ends meet.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles, Audra D. S. Burch, Richard Fausset and Michael Majchrowicz
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fort Myers Beach, Fla., was one of the communities hit hardest by Hurricane Ian.

item.title: The Cop Show Enters the ‘Defund’ Era
item.description: Widespread concerns over policing after the killing of George Floyd did not end the police drama as we know it. But shows are evolving to reflect the new climate.
item.dc:creator: Marc Tracy
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times

item.title: Nobel Prize in Physics Is Awarded to 3 Scientists for Work in Quantum Technology
item.description: Alain Aspect, John F. Clauser and Anton Zeilinger were recognized for their experiments in an area that has broad implications for secure information transfer and quantum computing.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai, Cora Engelbrecht and Dennis Overbye
item.media:credit: Jonas Ekstromer/TT News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Awarding the prize on Tuesday, the committee said that the scientists’ work had “opened doors to another world.”

item.title: What Video Footage Reveals About the Protests in Iran
item.description: The New York Times analyzed dozens of videos circulating online for insights about what is propelling the demonstrations, and how women are leading the movement.
item.dc:creator: Nilo Tabrizy and Haley Willis

item.title: North Korea Fires Ballistic Missile Over Japan in Major Escalation
item.description: The missile flew about 2,800 miles, the longest distance ever traveled by a North Korean missile, officials in Tokyo and Seoul said.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun and Motoko Rich
item.media:credit: Kimimasa Mayama/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A screen displaying news reporting of North Korea’s launch of a ballistic missile, in Tokyo, Japan, on Tuesday. North Korea launched a ballistic missile over Japan that landed in the Pacific Ocean, the exclusive economic zone (EEZ) of Japan, about 3000km east of Japan.

item.title: How Strong Is North Korea’s Military?
item.description: The country has one of the largest standing armies in the world, but much of its equipment is old. Leaders have sought to make up for that shortcoming by building new weapons.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun and Victoria Kim

item.title: At Long Last, Can Malaria Be Eradicated?
item.description: Two new vaccines may finally turn back an ancient plague. But in unexpected ways, their arrival also complicates the path to ending the disease.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli and Kang-Chun Cheng
item.media:credit: Kang-Chun Cheng for The New York Times

item.title: The Influential Group Helping Eric Adams Identify a Vision for New York
item.description: Created by the mayor’s allies, the 5Boro Institute seeks to counter concerns that the administration lacks a robust agenda to address the city’s problems.
item.dc:creator: Jeffery C. Mays and Dana Rubinstein
item.media:credit: Benjamin Norman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Eric Adams said that the think tank is part of a broad-based effort “dedicated to building a government that does things differently.”

item.title: Climate Change for Preschoolers: A TV Show Explores Unmapped Ground
item.description: There are almost no books, TV shows or other tools to help parents and teachers talk to preschoolers about climate change. “Octonauts: Above and Beyond” is one of the first to try.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times

item.title: The Deadly Collision of Racism and Mental Illness
item.description: How can we talk honestly about when mentally ill people commit hate crimes?
item.dc:creator: Eyal Press
item.media:credit: Illustration by Mike McQuade. Photograph by Getty Images/EyeEm Premium

item.title: The Failed Quest for Community Mental Health Centers in the U.S.
item.description: America has neglected people with serious mental illnesses for far too long.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: What a Conservative Therapist Thinks About U.S. Politics and Mental Health
item.description: Conservatives need mental health help too. But do they need to get it from someone who shares their worldview?
item.dc:creator: Meghan Daum
item.media:credit: David Williams for The New York Times

item.title: The All Too Real Risk of a Global Recession
item.description: We now find ourselves in the midst of the most comprehensive tightening of monetary policy the world has seen.
item.dc:creator: Adam Tooze
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; images via Getty Images

item.title: The Supreme Court Seems Awfully Nervous About Its Own Legitimacy
item.description: If justice after justice finds it necessary to defend the court’s power, what does that tell you?
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:credit: Sarah van Rij for The New York Times

item.title: How Liz Truss Did So Much Damage in So Few Days
item.description: The new government squandered its credibility.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Leon Neal/Getty Images
item.media:description: Kwasi Kwarteng, left, the chancellor of the Exchequer, and Prime Minister Liz Truss.

item.title: Boys and Men Are in Crisis Because Society Is
item.description: A new book has the right diagnosis, but its solutions are too small.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.category: Of Boys and Men: Why the Modern Male Is Struggling, Why It Matters, and What to Do about It (Book)
item.media:credit: September Dawn Bottoms for The New York Times

item.title: Popcast Live! The New Faces of 2022
item.description: Blondshell, Central Cee, Ethel Cain and more: a conversation about what’s breaking through, plus questions from the audience at our first live taping.
item.media:credit: Irina Rozovsky for The New York Times

item.title: It’s Time to Take Democrats’ Chances in the House Seriously
item.description: No, they are not favored. But the notion of retaining the chamber is not as far-fetched as it once was.
item.dc:creator: Nate Cohn
item.media:credit: Manuel Balce Ceneta/Associated Press
item.media:description: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and the House minority leader, Kevin McCarthy, before the memorial service last month for Queen Elizabeth II in Washington. Republicans are favored to retake the House.

item.title: How to Strengthen Your Bones and Reduce Osteoporosis Risk
item.description: A new study predicts hip fractures will nearly double worldwide by 2050. Here’s how to avoid them.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Matt Chase

item.title: TikTok’s Corn Kid Is Doing Just Fine: The Week in Narrated Articles
item.description: Five articles from around The Times, narrated just for you.
item.media:credit: OK McCausland for The New York Times
item.media:description: A video of Tariq took off online when he shared his love of corn.

item.title: Herschel Walker Paid for an Abortion for Ex-Girlfriend, Report Says
item.description: Mr. Walker called the report a lie, after The Daily Beast, which has also broken news about Mr. Walker’s out-of-wedlock children, reported that a former girlfriend had the procedure in 2009.
item.dc:creator: Maya King
item.media:credit: Nicole Craine for The New York Times
item.media:description: Herschel Walker campaigning in July in Georgia. He has faced a number of damaging reports about his life story since he began his campaign for Senate in 2021.

item.title: Trial Opens for Bruce Lehrmann, Man Accused of Rape in Australia’s Parliament House
item.description: The trial of the Australian man accused of sexually assaulting Brittany Higgins will be viewed against the backdrop of the global #MeToo movement.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Mick Tsikas/Australian Associated Press, via Reuters
item.media:description: Brittany Higgins arriving at Supreme Court in Canberra, Australia, on Tuesday.

item.title: Area Man Is Arrested for Parody. The Onion Files a Supreme Court Brief.
item.description: “Americans can be put in jail for poking fun at the government?” the satirical website asked in a friend-of-the-court brief filed Monday. “This was a surprise to America’s Finest News Source.”
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:credit: Photo by Justin Sullivan/Getty Images
item.media:description: The Onion ended its weekly print edition in 2009, but remains popular online. On Monday, the humor website took the unusual step of filing a brief with the Supreme Court on behalf of a man who had been jailed over a Facebook parody.

item.title: Tribal Pot Shops Thrive in New York
item.description: More than 100 marijuana dispensaries, run out of gas stations and wooden shacks, have opened on Native land while New York State awaits its first official retail licenses.
item.dc:creator: Jay Root and Jesse McKinley
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Many of the tribal-run marijuana dispensaries in New York operate out of gas stations like this one in Steamburg, a hamlet in Cattaraugus County.

item.title: How Hard Should Your Workout Be?
item.description: Every strenuous exercise involves some mixture of suffering and pleasure. The key to sticking with it is getting the balance right.
item.dc:creator: Alex Hutchinson
item.media:credit: Sean Dong

item.title: What Types of Exercise Reduce Dementia Risk?
item.description: Several large studies have confirmed that vigorous exercise, walking and even doing household chores can greatly benefit the brain.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: Is Pilates as Good as Everyone Says?
item.description: The strength and flexibility workout is having a moment. What can — and can’t — it do for us?
item.dc:creator: Danielle Friedman
item.media:credit: Melissa Schriek for The New York Times

item.title: How to Add a Jump Rope to Your Workout Routine
item.description: A jump rope can increase your agility and speed while giving you a great workout in half the time of a run.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Fairbank
item.media:credit: Ryan Young for The New York Times

item.title: Book Review: “Breathless,” by David Quammen
item.description: In “Breathless,” David Quammen explores the predictable lead-up to the global Covid pandemic, and the frantic, belated attempts to stop it.
item.dc:creator: Michael Sims
item.category: Breathless: The Scientific Race to Defeat a Deadly Virus (Book)
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: New Jersey first responder Robert Sabia being decontaminated after answering a call in March, 2020.

item.title: How to Solve Intermediate Crosswords
item.description: Moving up to the Wednesday and Thursday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
